data.description: From the sweet little farm at the foot of Penn’s Hill to the gentleman’s country estate at Peace field, Adams National Historical Park is the story of “heroes, statesman, philosophers … and learned women” whose ideas and actions helped to transform thirteen disparate colonies into one united nation.

entranceFees.description:
Individual tour tickets and annual digtital pass can be purchased on Recreation.gov or at the Adams National Historical Park Visitor Center.

The entrance fee is for all visitors age 16 and older.  Children under 16 are free. Credit or Debit Card only.
entranceFees.title: Individual Entrance Fee - 2023

data.directionsInfo: Traveling on U.S. Interstate 93, take exit 7 - Route 3 South to Braintree and Cape Cod. Take the first exit off Route 3 south - exit 42 - and follow signs toward Quincy Center. Continue straight on Burgin Parkway through six traffic lights. At the seventh traffic light, turn right onto Dimmock Street. Follow Dimmock Street one block and turn right onto Hancock Street. The National Park Service Visitor Center, located at 1250 Hancock Street on your left. Validated parking is in the garage to the rear.

operatingHours.description: The historic homes for Adams National Historical Park are now closed.  The Visitor Center will be open Monday to Friday, 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.  The historic homes are anticipated to reopen on May 3, 2023.
operatingHours.name: Winter Hours

images.title: The John and John Quincy Adams Birthplaces
images.altText: The Birthplaces of Presidents John Adams (right) and John Quincy Adams (left)
images.caption: The Birthplaces of John and John Quincy Adams sit right next  to each other on Franklin Street.

images.title: The Birthplace of John Adams

images.caption: The house where President John Adams was born in 1735.

images.title: The Birthplace of John Quincy Adams
images.altText: The Birthplace of John Quincy Adams
images.caption: The house where President John Quincy Adams was born in 1767.

images.title: Old House at Peace field
images.altText: A view of Old House at Peace field
images.caption: Old House at Peace field, where four generations of the Adams family lived from 1788 to 1927.

images.title: The Paneled Room
images.altText: The Paneled Room located inside Old House at Peace field.
images.caption: The Paneled Room greets everyone who enters Old House at Peace field.

images.title: The Stone Library
images.altText: The Stone Library located outside Old House at Peace field.
images.caption: The Stone Library houses up to 14,000 books belonging to the Adams family.

images.title: Inside the Stone Library
images.altText: Inside the Stone Library
images.caption: A view into the Stone Library

images.title: The Gardens Located at Old House at Peace field
images.altText: The gardens located at Old House at Peace field.
images.caption: The gardens located by Old House at Peace field bloom in every color you can imagine.

data.weatherInfo: Be prepared for hot, humid weather. The historic homes are not air conditioned. While the visitor center remains open all year, the historic homes are closed from November 1 through April 30.
data.name: Adams

data.description: The Appalachian Trail is a 2,180+ mile long public footpath that traverses the scenic, wooded, pastoral, wild, and culturally resonant lands of the Appalachian Mountains. Conceived in 1921, built by private citizens, and completed in 1937, today the trail is managed by the National Park Service, US Forest Service, Appalachian Trail Conservancy, numerous state agencies and thousands of volunteers.

entranceFees.description: The Appalachian National Scenic Trail (NST) does not charge an entrance fee for use of the trail on Appalachian NST land.
entranceFees.title: Appalachian National Scenic Trail Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo: There are many points of access along the Appalachian Trail, whether it is by car, train, bus or plane. For more detailed directions, please refer to the "Directions" section of our park webpage.

operatingHours.description:
In general, the Appalachian Trail is open year-round. The northern terminus at Mount Katahdin in Maine is within Baxter State Park, which may be closed in winter months, depending on weather conditions. 
Particular sections of the Trail, and less-developed roads accessing the Trail, may be closed temporarily for a number of reasons, but otherwise the trail is open.
operatingHours.name: Appalachian National Scenic Trail

images.title: McAfee Knob
images.altText: Silhouette of a man with backpack standing on McAfee Knob at sunset with mountains in the distance.
images.caption: McAfee Knob is one of the most popular locations along the A.T. to take photographs.

images.title: Appalachian Trail
images.altText: The Appalachian Trail runs across a mountain ridge line with views to the horizon of mountain range.
images.caption: Crossing into thirteen states, hikers experience a variety of scenery along the way.

images.title: The Infamous White Blaze of the A.T.
images.altText: A white blaze marks a tree in the foreground, with a man and child walking away on the wooded trail.
images.caption: The white blaze marks the Appalachian Trail as a way for hikers to identify the route.

images.credit: Photo Credit: Maine Appalachian Trail Club
images.title: Volunteer on the A.T.
images.altText: A volunteer is carrying a split log while walking across a wooden footbridge in the woods.
images.caption: The Appalachian Trail is maintained largely by volunteers.

images.title: Winter on the A.T.
images.altText: A snowy winter view from the A.T. overlooking snowy mountains and clouds in the distance.
images.caption: Hikers can experience many seasons along the A.T. all year round. It is important to be prepared.

data.weatherInfo: It is your responsibility to be prepared for all weather conditions, including extreme and unexpected weather changes year-round. As the trail runs from Georgia to Maine there will be different weather conditions depending on your location. For weather along specific sections of the trail and at specific shelters, please refer to: http://www.atweather.org/
data.name: Appalachian

data.fullName: Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park
data.description: The Blackstone River powered America's entry into the Age of Industry. The success of Samuel Slater's cotton spinning mill in Pawtucket, RI touched off a chain reaction that changed how people worked and where they lived, and continues to reverberate across the nation to this day. Come visit and see how this revolution transformed the landscape of the Blackstone Valley and then the United States.

entranceFees.description: At this point, the National Park Service does not charge any fees at the Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park. However, some of our partner sites do charge fees, as these sites are run by private, non-profit organizations.
entranceFees.title: Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park

entrancePasses.description: At this time, annual passes cannot be purchased from the Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park as we do not have a store yet.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Pass

data.directionsInfo: The park headquarters is located at the Wilkinson Mill in the Historic Slater Mill Complex in Pawtucket, RI. 67 Roosevelt Avenue Pawtucket, RI 02860 401-428-3816

operatingHours.description:
The park grounds are open from Sunrise to Sunset.  Slater Mill is open Thursday - Sunday from 10 AM to 4 PM for visitor services.

The headquarters are located at Slater Mill
67 Roosevelt Ave
Pawtucket, RI 02860

401-521-7266
operatingHours.name: Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park

data.name: Blackstone River Valley

data.fullName: Boston African American National Historic Site
data.description: Centered on the north slope of Beacon Hill, the African American community of 1800s Boston led the city and the nation in the fight against slavery and injustice. These remarkable men and women, together with their allies, were leaders in the Abolition Movement, the Underground Railroad, the Civil War, and the early struggle for equal rights and education.

emailAddresses.description: Please use this email for general inquiries.

entranceFees.description: Ranger guided walking tours of the Black Heritage Trail through the neighborhood.
entranceFees.title: Walking Tours of the Black Heritage Trail

entranceFees.description: Adult admission
entranceFees.title: Museum of African American History

entranceFees.description: Students and 62 and older
entranceFees.title: Museum of African American History

entranceFees.description: 12 and under
entranceFees.title: Museum of African American History

entranceFees.description: Boston Public School Students
entranceFees.title: Museum of African American History

entrancePasses.description: There are no entrance passes for this site.  Ranger guided walking tours are free of charge.  Our partner, the Museum of African American History charges an admission fee.
entrancePasses.title: There are no entrance passes for this site.

data.directionsInfo: Site administrative offices are located at 15 State Street. However, Ranger programs begin at either the Robert Gould Shaw Memorial on Beacon Street, or at the Museum of African American History at 46 Joy Street on Beacon Hill.

operatingHours.description: Boston African American National Historic Site rangers offer tours of the Black Heritage Trail seasonally. Please check the park calendar for available tours and programs.
operatingHours.name: Boston African American National Historic Site

operatingHours.description: The Museum of African American History is a partner of Boston African American National Historic Site. They operate the Abiel Smith School and the African Meeting House in conjunction with the National Park Service.
operatingHours.name: Museum of African American History

addresses.line2: Boston African American National Historical Site
Boston African American National Historical Site

images.title: The African Meeting House
images.altText: View from the pulpit at the African Meeting House
images.caption: The African Meeting House served as the religious, educational, and political center of Boston's 19th century African American community.

images.title: The William Cooper Nell House
images.altText: A yellow wooden house on Beacon Hill
images.caption: This is the home of education activist, abolitionist, and historian William Cooper Nell.

images.title: The Robert Gould Shaw Memorial
images.altText: A large bronze statue showing a man on horseback and soldiers walking alongside him
images.caption: The Robert Gould Shaw Memorial honors Colonel Shaw and the Massachusetts 54th, the first African American regiment from the North to fight in the Civil War.

images.title: Flowers at the Shaw Memorial
images.altText: A close up image of flowers laid at the feet of the soldiers on the Shaw Memorial
images.caption: Flowers laid at the feet of the soldiers on the Robert Gould Shaw Memorial.

images.title: The Lewis and Harriet Hayden House
images.altText: The entrance door into a red brick townhouse on Beacon Hill
images.caption: Lewis and Harriet Hayden used their home as an Underground Railroad safe house to shelter those running away from slavery.

data.weatherInfo: Boston African American National Historic Site is located in downtown Boston which can see extreme cold in the winter months, as well as extreme heat and humidity throughout the summer months. Walking tours may be cancelled during severe heat and/or weather events.
data.name: Boston African American

data.fullName: Boston Harbor Islands National Recreation Area
data.description: . . . where you can walk a Civil War-era fort, visit historic lighthouses, explore tide pools, hike lush trails, camp under the stars, or relax while fishing, picnicking or swimming-all within reach of downtown Boston. Youth programs, visitor services, research, wildlife management, and more are coordinated on the park's 34 islands and peninsulas by the Boston Harbor Islands Partnership.

entranceFees.description:
Boston Harbor Islands is a Partnership park; fees and reservations vary. 

The park does not charge an admission fee, but a transportation fee applies for the public ferry. Reservations are recommended. Please note that National Park Land Passes do not cover transportation fees.

Visit bostonharborislands.org to plan your trip.
entranceFees.title: Fees and Reservations Vary

data.directionsInfo: There are many ways to enjoy Boston Harbor Islands and many ways to get there. For more information on how to get to the park by ferry, car, or private boat, please visit www.bostonharborislands.org.

operatingHours.description:
Boston Harbor Islands is a Partnership park. Operating hours and seasons vary.

Visit bostonharborislands.org to plan your trip.
operatingHours.name: Boston Harbor Islands

images.title: Beach Dancing

images.caption: A child dancing on the beach at dusk

images.caption: Kayaking in Boston Harbor Islands National Recreational Area

images.title: Sunset Over Boston
images.altText: An image of the sun setting over the Boston skyline from the Islands
images.caption: Watch the sunset from Boston Harbor Islands

images.title: Come Explore The Islands
images.altText: Children looking out at Boston from the Harbor Islands
images.caption: Looking out at the city from the Boston Harbor Islands

images.title: Fort Warren
images.altText: Historic Fort Warren on Georges Island
images.caption: Visit historic Fort Warren on Georges Island in Boston Harbor

data.weatherInfo: The Boston Harbor Islands have a humid maritime climate characterized by slightly cooler temperatures than the mainland, so dress in layers. Typical summer conditions feature air temperatures approximately 5-10 degrees cooler than the mainland between 60-80 Fahrenheit, winds of 0-15 knots and waves of 1-3 feet.
data.name: Boston Harbor Islands

data.description: Discover how one city could be the Cradle of Liberty, site of the first major battle of American Revolution, and home to many who espoused that freedom can be extended to all.

entranceFees.description:
There are no fees at the federally or municipally owned historic sites within Boston National Historical Park, including Faneuil Hall, Bunker Hill Monument, Bunker Hill Museum, USS Constitution, and the Dorchester Heights Monument.

Fees and suggested donations are collected at the park's privately owned and operated partner sites. These sites are maintained and run by self-supporting historical associations working cooperatively with Boston National Historical Park.
entranceFees.title: For Admission to Historic Sites in the Park

data.directionsInfo: Visitor Centers are located at Historic Faneuil Hall, 1 Faneuil Hall Sq, and the Charlestown Navy Yard, Building 5. Go to the Directions page for more detailed information.

operatingHours.description:
Boston National Historical Park is a unique collaboration of federally, municipally, and privately owned and operated historic sites. Most of the park is along Boston's Freedom Trail®, a 2.5 mile (4 km) walking path marked by a red brick or painted line weaving through Downtown Boston, the North End, and Charlestown.

The trail itself is outdoors and open year round. Every site along the trail has its own hours which vary throughout the season. Please check ahead before planning your visit.
operatingHours.name: Boston National Historical Park

operatingHours.description: Please note: Only 20 people are allowed in the Monument at a time. The last climb is 30 minutes before closing. The Monument may close for climbing due to weather conditions and/or other safety considerations.
operatingHours.name: Bunker Hill Monument

operatingHours.description: Dorchester Heights marks the site of George Washington's first Revolutionary War victory. Located atop the last remaining hill in South Boston fortified by the Continental Army, the park grounds are open from dawn to dusk. The monument is currently not open to the public.
operatingHours.name: Dorchester Heights

operatingHours.description:
Located in the heart of downtown on the market floor of the historic 1742 building, the Faneuil Hall Visitor Center is the main visitor center for Boston National Historical Park and Boston African American National Historic Site. Maps and information for the Freedom Trail and Black Heritage trail are available here. Tours begin here seasonally.

Ranger services are temporarily unavailable at the first floor of Faneuil Hall. Rangers are available on the second floor.
operatingHours.name: Faneuil Hall

operatingHours.description:
The Paul Revere House is a Boston National Historical Park partner site operated by the Paul Revere Memorial Association.

The Paul Revere House is committed to operating as safely as possible. The Paul Revere House encourages masks for everyone inside buildings.
operatingHours.name: Paul Revere House

operatingHours.description: Old North is a Boston National Historical Park partner site operated by Old North Illuminated.
operatingHours.name: Old North Church

operatingHours.description:
The Old State House is a Boston National Historical Park partner site operated by Revolutionary Spaces.

For more visitor information, please visit the Revolutionary Spaces website.
operatingHours.name: Old State House

operatingHours.description:
The Old South Meeting House is a Boston National Historical Park partner site operated by Revolutionary Spaces.

For more visitor information, please visit the Revolutionary Spaces website.
operatingHours.name: Old South Meeting House

operatingHours.description:
The Great Hall is operated as a historic site by the National Park Service in partnership with the City of Boston. Faneuil Hall is owned and managed by the City of Boston. The Great Hall is closed to public visitation when City-permitted events are scheduled.

Visitors can find maps and other visiting materials in the Great Hall.
operatingHours.name: The Great Hall of Faneuil Hall

operatingHours.description: USS Constitution is the oldest commissioned ship in the United States Navy. Naval officers and crew still serve aboard her. The Navy operates the ship as a historic site in cooperation with the National Park Service.
operatingHours.name: USS Constitution

operatingHours.description:
USS Constitution Museum collects, preserves, and interprets the stories of "Old Ironsides." The museum is a partner of Boston National Historical Park located in the Charlestown Navy Yard.

The USS Constitution Museum is committed to providing a safe and enjoyable experience for visitors. In accordance with guidelines set by the Center for Disease Control, the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and the City of Boston, masks are optional for visitors and staff at the USS Constitution Museum.
operatingHours.name: USS Constitution Museum

operatingHours.description: USS Cassin Young is a Fletcher Class destroyer docked in the Charlestown Navy Yard. Park staff operate the ship seasonally. Weather conditions may alter hours without advanced notice.
operatingHours.name: USS Cassin Young

images.caption: Commandant's House is the oldest structure in the Charlestown Navy Yard.

data.weatherInfo: Temperatures range from warm, humid summer days to cold New England winter days. Wear comfortable sportswear in season, with comfortable walking shoes.
data.name: Boston

data.description: The great Outer Beach described by Thoreau in the 1800s is protected within the national seashore. Forty miles of pristine sandy beach, marshes, ponds, and uplands support diverse species. Lighthouses, cultural landscapes, and wild cranberry bogs offer a glimpse of Cape Cod's past and continuing ways of life. Swimming beaches and walking and biking trails beckon today's visitors.

entranceFees.description: The daily vehicle beach entrance pass grants access to all six Cape Cod National Seashore-managed beach parking lots for one private vehicle. The pass must be purchased on the day of use and is good for that calendar day. Purchase at beach entrance stations during business hours. Fees are typically collected at the six beaches from late spring through the end of September.
entranceFees.title: Daily Beach Entrance Fee, Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: The daily beach entrance fee for motorcycles grants access to all six Cape Cod National Seashore-managed beach parking lots for one motorcycle. The pass must be purchased on the day of use and is good for that calendar day. Purchase at beach entrance stations during business hours. Fees are typically collected at the six beaches from late spring through the end of September.
entranceFees.title: Daily Beach Entrance Fee, Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: The daily beach entrance fee for pedestrians and bicyclists grants access to all six Cape Cod National Seashore-managed beaches for one individual. Children 15 or under are free. The pass must be purchased on the day of use and is good for that calendar day. Purchase at beach entrance stations during business hours. Fees are typically collected at the six beaches from late spring through the end of September.
entranceFees.title: Daily Beach Entrance Fee, Pedestrian/Bicycle

entrancePasses.description: This pass provides private vehicle entrance into the six beach parking lots managed by the national seashore for the entirety of the park's charging season. This pass is in the form of a sticker affixed to the windshield of a vehicle and is not transferable. Purchase at beach entrance stations during business hours. Fees are typically collected at the six beaches from late spring through the end of September.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Private Vehicle Beach Entrance Pass to Cape Cod National Seashore

data.directionsInfo: The national seashore is located in eastern Massachusetts on Cape Cod and is accessed via Route 6. The park is 20 miles east of Hyannis, MA.

operatingHours.description: Beaches, parking areas, and trails are open year-round between 6 AM and midnight.
operatingHours.name: Cape Cod National Seashore

images.title: Sunrise Waves
images.altText: A curling wave breaks against the backdrop of a pink sunrise.
images.caption: Visiting the beach to watch the sunrise over the Atlantic Ocean is a beautiful experience.

images.title: Sand Ripples
images.altText: Low tide exposes rippled ridges of sand and water.
images.caption: You will never walk the same beach twice on Cape Cod; daily low and high tides expose and then cover the sand.

images.title: Exploring the Park by Water
images.altText: A red kayak floats on a pond facing a forest colored with red and orange leaves.
images.caption: Exploring the park by water offers a different perspective.

images.title: Birds and Beach
images.altText: A flock of birds flies along a beach with waves in the background.
images.caption: The national seashore is known for its species diversity, including threatened and endangered shorebirds.

images.title: Atlantic White Cedar Swamp Trail
images.altText: Boardwalk trail runs through a swamp surrounded by green ferns and tall trees.
images.caption: This popular trail takes visitors through the rare habitat of an Atlantic White Cedar swamp.

images.title: Sunrise Over the Atlantic
images.altText: A brilliant sun rises over the ocean reflecting light on the water's surface.
images.caption: Cape Cod provides the opportunity to watch the sun rise out of the Atlantic Ocean and set into Cape Cod Bay.

data.weatherInfo: Cape Cod's weather is generally moderated by its proximity to the ocean. Winter is typically cold with some snow. Spring is often rainy. Summer is usually warm and humid. Fall is generally dry and clear.
data.name: Cape Cod

data.fullName: Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site
data.description: Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903) is recognized as the founder of American landscape architecture and the nation's foremost parkmaker. Olmsted moved his home to suburban Boston in 1883 and established the world's first full-scale professional office for the practice of landscape design. During the next century, his sons and successors perpetuated Olmsted's design ideals, philosophy, and influence.

entranceFees.description: No entrance fee required.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo: Site is located on the southwest corner of Warren and Dudley Streets in Brookline, south of Route 9, near the Brookline Reservoir. Site is 0.7 miles from the Brookline Hills MBTA stop on the Green Line, D Branch.

operatingHours.description: Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site is closed beginning November 6- late April 2023. Reserved tours may be accommodated based on staff availability. Please call 617-566-1689 ext 238 to arrange.
operatingHours.name: Winter Hours

images.title: Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site
images.altText: Fairsted
images.caption: Fairsted, the home and office of landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted. Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site.

images.title: Drafting Table
images.altText: Dark wood box with four shallow drawers on large wooden table with blueprint
images.caption: A box of colored pencils and a draftsmen's handbook sit on a table in the drafting room. These materials reflect the period during which Frederick Law Olmsted, Jr. was the senior partner in the Brookline, MA landscape architecture firm.

images.title: The Hollow
images.altText: A shaded bench and plants in a sunken garden surrounded by bushes
images.caption: Landscape Architect Frederick Law Olmsted designed the Hollow on his Brookline, MA property to be a peaceful, picturesque sunken garden.

data.weatherInfo: Summer: Warm temperatures, average high temperature around 80 degrees Fahrenheit, often with humidity. July and August bring the hottest temperatures. Fall: Cooler temperatures, mean temperatures between 45 and 65 degrees Fahrenheit, sometimes rainy. Peak fall foliage is in mid-October. Winter: Cold, with snow, average low temperature around 25 degrees Fahrenheit. Spring: Cold to cool temperatures, average mean temperatures between 40 and 60 degrees Fahrenheit.
data.name: Frederick Law Olmsted

data.fullName: John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site
data.description: As a boy, JFK’s parents never expected he would grow up to be president. Yet in his birthplace home he learned values that inspired a life in public service. His mother, Rose Kennedy, recreated her family’s first home to share her memories of those early years with visitors. We commemorate not only his early life, but the ideas and principles he left behind.

entranceFees.description: All tours of the John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site are free of charge.
entranceFees.title: None

data.directionsInfo: By Subway: Take Green line ("C" -Cleveland Circle) trolley to Coolidge Corner stop. Walk four blocks north on Harvard Street, turn right on Beals Street and continue to number 83. By Car: From Exit 18 (I-90 E) or Exit 20 (1-90 W) follow the Allston/Brighton exit ramp, merge onto Cambridge Street and go one mile. At the fourth light, turn left on Harvard Street and proceed about one mile. Turn left on Beals Street and go to number 83. Limited Street Parking available.

operatingHours.description: The site is closed through 2022 for needed maintenance and Visitor Center renovations. The newly renovated Visitor Center will offer greater accessibility and make more efficient use of the space. Offsite programs, as they become available, will be listed on the park website: www.nps.gov/jofi
operatingHours.name: Closed for Visitor Center Renovations

images.title: John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site
images.altText: John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site
images.caption: Photograph of the birthplace of John F. Kennedy on Beals st. in Brookline, MA

images.title: Nursery
images.altText: Room with white wicker furniture, including bassinet and rocking chair. Long white baby dress hangs.
images.caption: The Kennedy christening gown on a stand next to the bassinet in which all the Kennedy children slept, at the John F. Kennedy National Historic Site.

images.title: Kennedy Dining Room
images.altText: Dining room with oval dining table with six place settings of silver and fine china.
images.caption: The dining table is set with the fine china and silver that Rose Kennedy received as a wedding present.

data.weatherInfo: Typical New England Weather: Warm, humid summers and cold winters. Any available outdoor programs take place rain or shine.
data.name: John Fitzgerald Kennedy

data.fullName: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site
data.description: Longfellow House-Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site preserves the home of Henry W. Longfellow, one of the world’s foremost 19th century poets. The house also served as headquarters for General George Washington during the Siege of Boston, July 1775 - April 1776. In addition to its rich history, the site offers unique opportunities to explore 19th century literature and arts.

entranceFees.description: Longfellow House-Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site is a fee free site. This includes all tours and special events.
entranceFees.title: Fee Information

data.directionsInfo: Longfellow House-Washington's Headquarters NHS is located in a residential section of Cambridge, MA. There is very little public parking in the area and onsite parking is limited to vehicles with handicapped parking permits. However, the site is a short walk from Harvard Square, where there are paid parking lots and a station for the MBTA Red Line and numerous bus routes. The use of public transportation to the site is highly recommended. Follow the link for detailed instructions.

operatingHours.description: The site is open for tours May 27-October 31, 2022. The grounds and garden are open year round daily, dawn-dusk.
operatingHours.name: Operating Hours

images.credit: NPS Photo / James P. Jones | Photography RI

images.caption: Special events create fun for all ages.

images.credit: NPS Photo / James P. Jones | Photography RI
images.title: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's Study
images.altText: View of a study with a round center table cluttered with books and writing implements.
images.caption: The Longfellow study table is cluttered with books and writing implements. The black "Chestnut Tree Chair" was a gift to Henry Longfellow in honor of his poem, "The Village Blacksmith."

images.credit: NPS Photo / James P. Jones | Photography RI
images.title: Front Hall
images.altText: A staircase with white balusters and green carpet. A bust of Washington sits at the turn of stairs.
images.caption: The Longfellows' iconic front entry features a bust of Washington at the turn of the stairs

images.title: Longfellow House-Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site
images.altText: mansion highlighted by the changing colors of fall
images.caption: Thousands tour the historic headquarters of George Washington and home of Henry Longfellow each summer.

images.title: The General Finds His Park
images.altText: reenactors in front of house
images.caption: You never know who you might find!

images.title: Longfellow Family Garden
images.altText: garden back dropped by house
images.caption: The Longfellow Family Garden provides a peaceful getaway in the heart of Cambridge.

images.title: Summer Festival Concert
images.altText: large crowd on the east lawn listening to singers perfom
images.caption: Each year is highlighted by the Summer Festival on the house's east lawn.

images.title: Winter at Longfellow House-Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site
images.altText: house covered with new fallen snow
images.caption: New fallen snow blankets the historic mansion.

images.title: Longfellow Family Garden
images.altText: pink flower in garden
images.caption: Vibrant colors abound throughout the year in the Longfellow Family Garden.

data.weatherInfo: New England weather is highly variable. Temperatures in the winter can be very cold with high snowfall. Fall and spring are generally pleasant. Summer temperatures are generally mild, with periods of heat and humidity. However, the house is air conditioned and heated for collection care and the comfort of the visitor.
data.name: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters

data.description: Lowell’s water-powered textile mills catapulted the nation – including immigrant families and early female factory workers – into an uncertain new industrial era. Nearly 200 years later, the changes that began here still reverberate in our shifting global economy. Explore Lowell, a living testament to the dynamic human story of the industrial revolution.

entranceFees.description: Interpretive Demonstration fees at the Boott Mills Museum- $6 for Adults, $4 Senior (62+), $3 Student, $3 Youth (under 17), Free for 5 or under. Discounts for America the Beautiful Interagency Pass holders. Free for 4th grade holders of the Every Kid in a Park Pass.
entranceFees.title: Boott Cotton Mills Museum

entranceFees.description: 90 minute-2 hour Canal Boat Tours offered Memorial Day- Columbus Day. $12 adults, $10 Senior, $8 Student, $8 Youth (6-16 yrs.), Free for under 5.
entranceFees.title: Canal Boat Tour Fee

data.directionsInfo: From Interstate Route 495 take Exit 89C on to the Lowell Connector. From Route 3 take Exit 80A if traveling southbound, Exit 80B if traveling northbound. • Take the Lowell Connector to Exit 5B (Thorndike Street) • Continue right on to Thorndike Street, which becomes Dutton Street • At the third traffic light continue straight under the overpass • At the next light turn right. Free parking is available at the City garage. Follow signs and walk through the mill courtyard to reach the Visitor Center

operatingHours.description:
The Boott Cotton Mills Museum (115 John Street) is open Sunday - Friday from 12 p.m. - 5 p.m. and Saturday 10 a.m. - 5 p.m. (Through Spring 2023) 

The Visitor Center (246 Market Street) and Mill Girls Boardinghouse Exhibit (40 French Street) are closed until Spring 2023.
operatingHours.name: Lowell National Historical Park

operatingHours.description: Don't miss the roar of 85 operating power looms! The Boott Cotton Mills Museum (115 John Street) includes a recreated 1920s-era weave room, historical artifacts, interactive exhibits and video programs about the Industrial Revolution and the people of Lowell. Learn more about the city’s role as a cutting-edge developer of technology and hub of social and economic change in the American Industrial Revolution.
operatingHours.name: Boott Cotton Mills Museum

images.title: Boott Cotton Mills
images.altText: 5 story brick factories with a clocktower surrounding a central courtyard
images.caption: The Boott Cotton Mills is one of the best, most-intact complexes of cotton mills from Lowell's heyday in the 19th century.

images.title: Tsongas Center Programs
images.altText: Two students weaving on the looms at the education center.
images.caption: The Tsongas Industrial History Center, a partnership of Lowell National Historical Park and UMass Lowell's Graduate School of Education, offers hands-on interactive education workshops for more than 50,000 students each year.

images.title: Lowell NHP Trolley
images.altText: Streetcar guided through Lowell by motormen with lots of passengers
images.caption: Lowell National Historical Park operates reproduction vintage streetcars throughout the park and downtown Lowell. Climb onboard for a ride or a ranger-guided tour.

images.title: Boott Mills Weave Room
images.altText: Two young visitors look over the rail at a room full of working looms
images.caption: The working weave room at the Boott Cotton Mills Museum surrounds you with the sights and sounds of a turn-of-the-century working cotton textile factory.

images.title: Lowell Folk Festival
images.altText: Street scene with lots of tents and crowds listening to Folk Festival music at Boardinghouse Park.
images.caption: The Lowell Folk Festival, Lowell's signature annual event, brings traditional folk performers to 5 stages throughout the city and a huge variety of traditional ethnic foods from all around the world.

data.weatherInfo: Summer: Throughout the summer, temperatures range from the mid 60s to mid 90s during the day, with rain and thunderstorms more common in the months of July and August. Boats and trolleys operate rain or shine and are only cancelled in cases of extreme weather or the presence of thunder and lightning. Winter: Winters are typically cold with temperatures in the mid 30s and 40s (with occasional single digit temperatures) and snow storms with a few inches accumulation occur frequently throughout the season.
data.name: Lowell

data.description: At Minute Man National Historical Park the opening battle of the Revolution is brought to life as visitors explore the battlefields and structures associated with April 19, 1775, and witness the American revolutionary spirit through the writings of the Concord authors.

entranceFees.description:
No fee to visit Minute Man Visitor Center, North Bridge Visitor Center Hartwell Tavern, Whittemore House or park grounds. 

The Wayside: Home of Authors tour fee: Adults $7.00 Seniors and Students with ID $5.00. Children under 17 free.
entranceFees.title: Minute Man Fees

entrancePasses.description: This is a lifetime pass for U.S. citizens or permanent residents with permanent disabilities. Documentation is required to obtain the pass. Acceptable documentation includes: statement by a licensed physician; document issued by Federal agency such as the Veteran's Administration, Social Security Disability Income or Supplemental Security Income; or document issued by a State agency such as a vocational rehabilitation agency.
entrancePasses.title: Access Pass

entrancePasses.description: Available for current U.S. military members and dependents in the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, and Coast Guard as well as Reserve and National Guard members. Please bring a Common Access Card or Military ID (Form 1173)
entrancePasses.title: Free Annual Pass for U.S. Military

entrancePasses.description: Available for U.S. 4th graders (including home-schooled and free-choice learners 10 years of age) with a valid Every Kid Outdoors paper pass. Paper passes can be obtained by visiting the Every Kid Outdoors website and can be exchanged for the Annual 4th Grade Pass at federal recreation sites that charge Entrance or Standard Amenity fees (Day Use Fee)
entrancePasses.title: Annual 4th Grade Pass

data.directionsInfo: Minute Man National Historical Park is located just off of I-95, exit 46B (old exit 30B), Rt 2A west, starting in Lexington, then west through Lincoln and into Concord.

operatingHours.description: The grounds of Minute Man National Historical Park are open daily, sunrise to sunset. Parking lot gates close at sunset.
operatingHours.name: Minute Man National Historical Park

images.title: Concord Minute Man
images.altText: By daniel Chester French
images.caption: The embattled farmer stands guard over North Bridge, Concord.

images.title: Captain William Smith House
images.altText: Located on Battle Road, the Smith House was home of Captain John Smith of the Lincoln Militia.
images.caption: The Smith House is a witness to the days events of April 19, 1775.

images.title: Fifler
images.altText: a women in colonial clothes plays the fife.
images.caption: A fifer at the annual William Diamond Muster at the Minute Man Visitor Center

images.title: North Bridge
images.altText: A wooden bridge spans the Concord river as people walk and canoe paddlers gluide under the bridge
images.caption: North Bridge, Concord Massachusetts

images.title: Living History!
images.altText: A company of armed minute men stand in formation along a dirt road with the officer out in front.
images.caption: History comes alive!

images.title: The Battle Road Trail
images.altText: A narrow dirt track runs through green fields shaded by large trees.
images.caption: Walk in the footsteps of history

data.weatherInfo: New England weather can be quite unpredictable, so check the regional weather forecasts before you plan your trip. Winters can range in temperature from 20 - 50 degrees Fahrenheit. Summers are quite humid and range in temperature from 60 - 90 degrees Fahrenheit. Beware of ticks as they can be active year round.
data.name: Minute Man

data.fullName: New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park
data.description: "The town itself is perhaps the dearest place to live in, in all New England..nowhere in all America will you find more patrician-like houses, parks and gardens more opulent, than in New Bedford…all these brave houses and flowery gardens came from the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian oceans. One and all, they were harpooned and dragged up hither from the bottom of the sea." H. Melville, "Moby-Dick"

entranceFees.description: New Bedford Whaling National Historical is a fee free park. Fees are however collected at other privately owned and operated sites by self-supporting associations working cooperatively with the park, including partners. These sites rely on admission fees as they do not receive federal funding for operations and therefore do not accept the National Parks Pass for admission.
entranceFees.title: Fee Free

data.directionsInfo: From I-195 East or West take Exit 15 (Route 18 / Downtown). Take exit 15 to merge onto MA-18 S toward Downtown/New Bedford Continue straight onto MA-18 Turn right at the first set of lights, Elm St. Turn left onto Acushnet Ave Turn left onto William St Destination will be on the left

operatingHours.description:
New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park is an urban park located in the City of New Bedford. 

Holidays:
Closed on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, and New Year’s Day
operatingHours.name: New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park

images.title: National Park Visitor Center
images.altText: New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park Visitor Center on a bright fall day.
images.caption: New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park Visitor Center on a bright fall day.

images.caption: Semen's Bethel and Mariners' Home

images.altText: The sun setting over the Acushnet River in New Bedford.
images.caption: The sun setting over the Acushnet River in New Bedford.

images.title: Rodman Candleworks
images.altText: Sun shining on the front of Rodman Candleworks
images.caption: Rodman Candleworks

data.weatherInfo: Summer temperatures range from 56-83F. Fall temperatures range from 30-70F. Winter temperatures range from 20-45F. Spring temperatures range from 30-70F.
data.name: New Bedford Whaling

data.description: From the Sound to the Summits: the New England Trail covers 215 miles from Long Island Sound across long ridges to scenic mountain summits in Connecticut and Massachusetts. The trail offers panoramic vistas and close-ups of New England’s natural and cultural landscape: traprock ridges, historic village centers, farmlands, unfragmented forests, quiet streams, steep river valleys and waterfalls.

emailAddresses.description:
For information regarding the NET in Massachusetts, contact Bridge Likely at amcnenst@outdoors.org

For information regarding the NET in Connecticut, contact Clare Cain at ccain@ctwoodlands.org

entranceFees.description: There are no fees to hike the New England Trail. Overnight site fees vary, please visit http://www.newenglandtrail.org/get-on-the-trail/overnight-sites, for details and fees.
entranceFees.title: New England Trail Fees

data.directionsInfo: More than 100 public roads cross the New England Trail, and there are trail head parking areas at or near many of these crossings. Detailed Trail Maps are available from Appalachian Mountain Club and Connecticut Forest & Park Association. For Massachusetts maps, visit the AMC Berkshire Chapter; for Connecticut, visit the CFPA Bookstore. Direct access by bus is available at several points in Connecticut and Massachusetts. Train service is available at two points – in Guilford, CT and Northampton, MA.

operatingHours.description: As the New England trail crosses private property and state land, many locations along the trail do not permit night hiking or overnight parking. Before going out on a hike, check the hours of local parks for parking and hiking regulations.
operatingHours.name: New England Trail Hours

addresses.line2: c/o Springfield Armory National Historic Site
c/o Springfield Armory National Historic Site

images.title: Sunset on the trail
images.altText: Hiker in trees at overlook with sunset in background
images.caption: Scenic views on the New England Trail

images.title: Fall on the NET
images.altText: Fall trees on the mountains of the trail
images.caption: Fall on the New England Trail

images.title: Mt Tom Overlook
images.altText: Overview of the trail in the fall
images.caption: Mount Tom Overlook

images.title: NET College Network Retreat
images.altText: Youth gather around a trail head
images.caption: Youth hike to Farley Ledge

images.title: YAP on Mt Higby
images.altText: Two youth pointing out over the trail from the top of Mt Higby
images.caption: Hikers pointing out over Mount Higby

data.weatherInfo: Temperatures range from warm, humid summer days to cold New England winter days.
data.name: New England

data.description: Established on March 17, 1938 as the first National Historic Site in the United States, Salem Maritime National Historic Site consists of nine acres of land and twelve historic structures along the Salem waterfront, as well as a downtown visitor center. Located in the urban setting of Salem, the park preserves and interprets over 600 years of New England's maritime history and global connections.

entranceFees.description: Salem Maritime National Historic Site does not require an entrance fee. There are no fees for any park programs, tours or park films.
entranceFees.title: All Fees

data.directionsInfo: Salem Maritime National Historic Site is located in downtown Salem, Massachusetts and is accessible by vehicle, commuter rail, bus, ferry, and recreational boat.

operatingHours.description: All outdoor spaces including the grounds, gardens, waterfront, and wharves are accessible 7 days a week. Please check the visitor center hours to learn more about which facilities are open.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds

images.title: Friendship of Salem
images.altText: A three mast tall ship on the water under a blue sky with red brick buildings on the shore.
images.caption: Park Waterfront & Vessel Friendship of Salem

images.title: Custom House
images.altText: Three story red brick building with white columns has a wide staircase and golden eagle on top.
images.caption: This Custom House was built in 1819 and housed offices for the officers of the U.S. Customs Service, as well as an attached warehouse, the Public Stores, used for the storage of bonded and impounded cargo.

images.title: Derby Wharf Light
images.altText: A white rectangular lighthouse approximately 20 feet tall is near the water on a gravel road.
images.caption: The Derby Wharf Light Station has aided navigation in Salem Harbor since it was first lit in 1871.

images.title: Derby House
images.altText: Three story red brick building with white windows and a brick pathway through grasses and trees.
images.caption: Built in 1762 as a wedding present, the Derby House was the home of Elias Hasket Derby (1739-1799) and Elizabeth Crowninshield Derby (1727-1799) for the first twenty years of their marriage.

data.weatherInfo: New England weather is unpredictable year-round. Monthly averages, in degrees Fahrenheit, are: January: 37 high, 20 low February: 40 high, 23 low March: 47 high, 30 low April: 57 high, 38 low May: 67 high, 48 low June: 76 high, 58 low July: 82 high, 63 low August: 80 high, 62 low September: 73 high, 55 low October: 62 high, 45 low November: 52 high, 37 low December: 42 high, 27 low
data.name: Salem Maritime

data.fullName: Saugus Iron Works National Historic Site
data.description: In the 1600's, on the banks of the Saugus River, something extraordinary happened! Explore the place where European iron makers brought their special skills to a young Massachusetts colony. Saugus Iron Works is a twelve-acre National Historic Site that includes working waterwheels, forges, mills, a historic 17th century home, and a lush river basin.

entranceFees.description: Saugus Iron Works does not require an entrance fee. All tours, education programs, and community events are free.
entranceFees.title: Park Fee

data.directionsInfo: The park is accessible via Interstate 95 (Walnut St.) and Route 1 (Main St. / Walnut St.). Public transportation options are available through the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority (MBTA).

operatingHours.description: All outdoor spaces including the grounds and walking paths are accessible 7 days a week. Please check the visitor center hours to learn more about which facilities are open.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds

images.title: Saugus Iron Works Landscape
images.altText: Several wooden structures amid green fields and trees under partly cloudy sky and beside river.
images.caption: A view of Saugus Iron Works from the Saugus River

images.title: Iron Forge
images.altText: Approximately 15' by 15' spoked wooden wheel beside river and under blue sky.
images.caption: The forge is where bars of pig iron created at the blast furnace were changed into a new kind of iron that a blacksmith was able to use.

images.title: Blast Furnace
images.altText: Rectangular wooden structure between orange deciduous trees and wooden bridge with walkway.
images.caption: The blast furnace is where bog ore was smelted to create cast iron "pig" bars.

data.weatherInfo: New England weather is unpredictable year-round. Monthly averages, in degrees Fahrenheit, are: January: 37 high, 20 low February: 40 high, 23 low March: 47 high, 30 low April: 57 high, 38 low May: 67 high, 48 low June: 76 high, 58 low July: 82 high, 63 low August: 80 high, 62 low September: 73 high, 55 low October: 62 high, 45 low November: 52 high, 37 low December: 42 high, 27 low
data.name: Saugus Iron Works

data.description: For nearly two centuries, the U.S. Armed Forces and American industry looked to Springfield Armory for innovative engineering and superior firearms. Springfield Armory National Historic Site commemorates the critical role of the nation’s first armory by preserving and interpreting the world's largest historic US military small arms collection, along with historic archives, buildings and landscape.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to visit Springfield Armory National Historic Site
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description:
Entry to Springfield Armory National Historic Site is free of charge. 

Springfield Armory offers the following free passes:
Free Annual Pass for current US Military and their dependents
Free Annual Pass for US 4th Grade Students
Free Lifetime Access Pass for US Citizens or permanent residents medically determined to have a permanent disability.

The Park does not sell National Park Passes but they my be purchased at fee-based parks or online at: 
https://www.nps.gov/planyourvisit/passes.htm
entrancePasses.title: America The Beautiful Passes

data.directionsInfo: The entrance to Armory Square is on Federal Street in Springfield, MA. Armory Square is shared by Springfield Armory NHS and Springfield Technical Community College (STCC). The park is located on the STCC campus. Follow the one way roadway around until you see the entrance sign for the park. If stopped by campus security let them know you are visiting the park. Parking is available in front of the Springfield Armory visitor center.

operatingHours.description:
The Park MUSEUM & VISITOR CENTER
The Park is OPEN Wednesday through Sunday from 9:30am to 4:00pm. 
The Park is CLOSED Monday and Tuesday

The park is closed for the following holidays:

•New Year's Day
•Thanksgiving Day
•Christmas Day
operatingHours.name: Springfield Armory National Historic Site

images.title: Springfield Armory National Historic Site
images.altText: The Main Arsenal
images.caption: The Main Arsenal at Springfield Armory National Historic Site was first built in 1850 and today houses the park's amazing collection of historic firearms.

images.title: Blank Firing Demostration
images.altText: Three Park Volunteers, holding historic firearms, on the grounds of the Armory against a cloudy sky.
images.caption: Park Volunteers give a blank firing demonstration of historic firearms.

images.title: Springfield Armory Clock Tower
images.altText: The tower of the Armory with the flag at full mast blowing in the wind on a cloudy day.
images.caption: Following the closure of the Springfield Armory in 1968, public action would drive Congress to create Springfield Armory National Historic Site in the late 1970s.

images.title: Organ of Muskets
images.altText: A double musket rack holding 645 Springfield US Model 1861 rifle muskets.
images.caption: Named after a poem by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, the Organ of Muskets consists of 647 Model 1861 Rifle Muskets. This structure would have held 1100 muskets when fully stocked and would have been one of many that filled the Arsenal during the Civil War.

images.title: Springfield Main Arsenal on a Fall Day
images.altText: The Springfield Armory Main Arsenal on a fall day, with blue skies and the flag at half staff.
images.caption: Springfield Armory began the production of small arms in 1794 and continued until its close in 1968. In 1978, the Armory reopened under the direction of the National Park Service as a National Historic Site.

data.weatherInfo: Springfield Armory National Historic Site is situated in the heart of Western Massachusetts and the Pioneer Valley. Our year is marked by four distinct seasons. Summers tend to be pleasant, but can at times be very hot and very humid. Autumn features brilliant foliage and cooler, calmer weather. Winter storms are capable of closing the park and can make travel dangerous. Springtime in New England is pleasant.
data.name: Springfield Armory

data.fullName: Washington-Rochambeau Revolutionary Route National Historic Trail
data.description: In 1781, General Rochambeau’s French Army joined forces with General Washington’s Continental Army to fight the British Army in Yorktown, Virginia. With the French Navy in support, the allied armies moved hundreds of miles to become the largest troop movement of the American Revolution. The effort and cooperation between the two sides led to a victory at Yorktown and secured American independence.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to explore the Washington-Rochambeau Revolutionary Route National Historic Trail, but fees may apply for sites and attractions along the trail. Visitors should contact sites individually for further information.
entranceFees.title: Washington-Rochambeau Fee

data.directionsInfo: The Washington-Rochambeau Revolutionary Route National Historic Trail encompasses over 680 miles of land and water trails through Rhode Island, Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, Washington D.C., and Virginia

operatingHours.description: The Washington-Rochambeau Revolutionary Route NHT can be travelled year-round. The NHT connects national, state, and local parks as well a great number of historic sites and landmarks. Visitors should contact sites or attractions individually as operating hours vary widely by site and season.
operatingHours.name: Washington-Rochamebeau National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: Make requests of Trail Administrator at Johnny_Carawan@NPS.gov

images.title: Washington Rochambeau
images.altText: Flag marking the trail
images.caption: Washington-Rochambeau NHT banner on 2nd Street in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

data.weatherInfo: With over 680 miles of land and water trails and hundreds of historical sites, there is a wide variety in weather. Please check with your favorite weather website before traveling.
data.name: Washington-Rochambeau Revolutionary Route
